data.profileText: a Representative from Vermont; born in South Hadley, Hampshire County, Mass., October 30, 1770; graduated from Dartmouth College, Hanover, N.H., in 1797; studied law; admitted to the bar in 1800 and commenced practice in Pomfret, Vt.; register of probate for Windsor County 1800-1809; postmaster, Putney, Vt., 1801-1807; county attorney in 1813; judge of Windham County in 1814, 1815, 1817, and 1820; also judge of probate of the district of Westminster in 1814 and 1815; member of the constitutional convention in 1814; served in the Vermont state house of representatives, 1815-1820; unsuccessful candidate for election to the Fifteenth Congress in 1816; unsuccessful candidate for election to the Sixteenth Congress in 1818; elected as a Federalist to the Seventeenth Congress (March 4, 1821-March 3, 1823); unsuccessful candidate for reelection to the Eighteenth Congress in 1822; unsuccessful candidate for election to the Nineteenth Congress in 1824; member of the Vermont state constitutional convention in 1836; served in the Vermont state senate in 1836 and 1837; trustee of Middlebury College; died in Putney, Windham County, Vt., on July 6, 1847; interment in Maple Grove Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1843, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Phineas White to Daniel Webster written on February 9, 1843. In the letter, White writes that he does not approve of the veto power used by General Jackson or President Tyler, and hopes to see Webster become President. White also suggests a friend for a consulship.

researchRecord.name: 1801-1829. ca. 2 feet. Forms part of Stevens collection.
researchRecord.description: Personal and business papers and correspondence. Some papers are burned. Microfilm of papers originally held by the New York State Library. Finding aid in repository.
